a.g: Whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth exalts Allah, and He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
O you who have believed, why do you say what you do not do?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k09
Indeed, the meaning of His saying, exalted is He, "Why do you say what you do not do?" is the false promise [al-wa'd al-kadhib].

a.g: Great is hatred in the sight of Allah that you say what you do not do.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 1
Indeed, great is the abhorrence [mughta] with Allah that you say what you do not do. And by what has been narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, that he said: "On the night I was taken on the journey [isra], I passed by people whose lips were being clipped with shears of fire. I said, 'Who are you?' They said, 'We used to command good and not do it, and we used to forbid evil and do it.'" The hadith "I passed by people whose lips were being clipped with shears of fire on the night I was taken on the journey" has preceded in the chapter on Knowledge. And by what has been narrated that Allah, exalted is He, revealed to Jesus, peace be upon him: "Admonish yourself; if you are admonished, then admonish the people, otherwise be ashamed before Me." And perhaps they argued by way of analogy [qiyas] that guiding others is a branch of being guided oneself, and likewise, setting others straight is a branch of being upright [istiqamah] oneself, and reform [islah] is the purifying alms [zakat] from the minimum threshold [nisab] of righteousness [salah]. So how can one who is not righteous [salah] in himself reform another? And when will the shadow be straight if the stick is crooked? All that they have mentioned are illusions [khayalat]. Rather, the truth is that the corrupt person [fasiq] may enjoin good and forbid evil with sincere intention [ihtisab]. And its proof is that we say: Is it stipulated for enjoining good [ihtisab] that the one practicing it be infallible [ma'sum] from all sins? If that is stipulated, then it is a rupture of consensus [ijma'], and then it seals the door of enjoining good, for there is no infallibility for the Companions, let alone those below them. And concerning the Prophets, peace be upon them, there is disagreement regarding their infallibility from errors. And the Mighty Qur'an indicates the attribution of sin [ma'siyah] to Adam, peace be upon him, and likewise a group of the Prophets. And for this reason, Sa'id ibn Jubayr said: "If none were to command good [ma'ruf] and forbid evil [munkar] except one in whom there is no fault, then no one would command anything." And Malik was amazed at that from Sa'id ibn Jubayr.

a.g: Indeed, Allah loves those who fight in His cause in a row as though they are a [single] structure joined firmly.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book6
Know that the evidences of the Qur'an are mutually supporting in that Allah, the Exalted, loves His servant, so it is necessary to know the meaning of that. And let us first present the evidences for His love, for Allah, the Exalted, has said: "Indeed, Allah loves those who fight in His cause in ranks [ṣaffan]."

a.g: And [mention, O Muhammad], when Moses said to his people, "O my people, why do you harm me while you certainly know that I am the messenger of Allah to you?" And when they deviated, Allah caused their hearts to deviate. And Allah does not guide the defiantly disobedient people.

And [mention] when Jesus, the son of Mary, said, "O children of Israel, indeed I am the messenger of Allah to you confirming what came before me of the Torah and bringing good tidings of a messenger to come after me, whose name is Ahmad." But when he came to them with clear evidences, they said, "This is obvious magic."
And who is more unjust than one who invents about Allah untruth while he is being invited to Islam. And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah will perfect His light, although the disbelievers dislike it.
It is He who sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion, although those who associate others with Allah dislike it.
O you who have believed, shall I guide you to a transaction that will save you from a painful punishment?
[It is that] you believe in Allah and His Messenger and strive in the cause of Allah with your wealth and your lives. That is best for you, if you should know.
He will forgive for you your sins and admit you to gardens beneath which rivers flow and pleasant dwellings in gardens of perpetual residence. That is the great attainment.
And [you will obtain] another [favor] that you love - victory from Allah and an imminent conquest; and give good tidings to the believers.

O you who have believed, be supporters of Allah, as when Jesus, the son of Mary, said to the disciples, "Who are my supporters for Allah?" The disciples said, "We are supporters of Allah." And a faction of the Children of Israel believed and a faction disbelieved. So We supported those who believed against their enemy, and they became dominant.
